markdownRemark.html:
this

  • this refers to the execution context
  • it is determined by how the function was called
  • therefore, javascript becomes very flexible since the binding can be easily varied
  • the different ways to call functions in javascript -
    • implicit binding
    • dynamic binding
    • explicit binding - call, apply
    • hard binding - bind
    • default binding
    • using new keyword

Implicit Binding

this refers to workshop in the example below, because of the call site i.e. what calls it

var workshop = {
  teacher: "kyle",
  ask: function (question) {
    console.log(this.teacher, question)
  },
}

workshop.ask("why") // kyle why

Dynamic Binding

works the same way as implicit binding in terms of “this”

function ask(question) {
  console.log(this.teacher, question)
}

var workshop = {
  teacher: "kyle",
  ask,
}

workshop.ask("why") // kyle why

Explicit Binding

  • we specify the this we want to use
  • can have two variations, call and apply, which differ only in method signature
function ask(question, remark) {
  console.log(this.teacher, question, remark)
}

var workshop = { teacher: "kyle" }

ask.call(workshop, "why", "thankyou") // kyle why thankyou
ask.apply(workshop, ["why", "thankyou"]) // kyle why thankyou

Hard Binding

  • returns a new function
  • once we use bind, binding cannot be changed further
function ask(question) {
  console.log(this.teacher, question)
}

var workshop = { teacher: "kyle" }

ask.bind(workshop)("why") // kyle why

Default Binding

by default, this refers to the window in case of browser

function abc() {
  console.log(this)
}
abc() // logs the window object

var in global scope gets bound to the window, hence the output below.

var teacher = "kyle"

function ask(question) {
  console.log(this.teacher, question)
}

ask("why") // kyle why

to prevent default binding, ‘use strict’. then this refers to undefined by default

var teacher = "kyle"

function askAgain(question) {
  "use strict"
  console.log(this.teacher, question)
}

askAgain("why") // TypeError: Cannot read property 'teacher' of undefined

Arrow Functions and this

  • arrow functions have no this
  • they resolve to their closest parent scope’s this
  • so, in the example below, this would refer to workshop.ask’s this
  • workshop.ask’s this refers to workshop because of implicit binding
var workshop = {
  teacher: "kyle",

  ask(question) {
    setTimeout(() => {
      console.log(this.teacher, question)
    }, 100)
  },
}

workshop.ask("why") // kyle why

to get normal functions to behave like arrow functions we create a reference to parent scope’s this

var workshop = {
  teacher: "kyle",

  ask(question) {
    var _this = this
    setTimeout(function () {
      console.log(_this.teacher, question)
    }, 100)
  },
}

workshop.ask("why") // kyle why

we could have also used bind

var workshop = {
  teacher: "kyle",

  ask(question) {
    function perform() {
      console.log(this.teacher, question)
    }
    setTimeout(perform.bind(this), 100)
  },
}

workshop.ask("why") // kyle why

another example of how arrow functions work -

var teacher = "suzy"

var workshop = {
  teacher: "kyle",

  ask: (question) => {
    console.log(this.teacher, question)
  },
}

workshop.ask("why") // suzy why
workshop.ask.call(workshop, "why") // suzy why

this behavior was observed because -

  • var got associated to window
  • arrow function’s this refers to the closest parent scope, which in this case is the global scope window (objects don’t have scope). so, my understanding is that call has nothing to do with arrow functions

Classes

  • methods of classes are not bound to the instance by default
  • methods are on the prototype i.e. instances call the methods on prototype
class Teacher {
  constructor(teacher) {
    this.teacher = teacher
  }
}

class Question extends Teacher {
  constructor(teacher) {
    super(teacher)
  }

  ask(question) {
    console.log(this.teacher, question)
  }
}

var question = new Question("kyle")
question.ask("why") // kyle why

setTimeout(question.ask, 100, "why") // undefined why

Static

  • can be used for a property, method or the initialization block in a class
  • static methods or properties cannot be used from the instance, they should be used from the class itself
class Animal {
  static legs = ["foreleg", "hindleg"];
}

const a = new Animal();

a.legs // undefined
Animal.legs // exists

new Keyword

new does the following things -

  1. creates a new object
  2. links it to function’s prototype using __proto__
  3. calls the function with this referring to the new object
  4. returns the new object
function ask(question) {
  this.teacher = "kyle"
  console.log(this.teacher, question)
}

var retVal = new ask("why") // kyle why
console.log(retVal.__proto__ === ask.prototype) // true (proof of point 2)
console.log(retVal.teacher) // kyle (proof of points 3 and 4)

Prototypes

  • constructor makes an object linked to its own prototype
  • note: arrow functions don’t have prototypes, they don’t work with new

example using prototypes -

function Workshop(teacher) {
  this.teacher = teacher
}

Workshop.prototype.ask = function ask(question) {
  console.log(this.teacher, question)
}

var workshop = new Workshop("kyle")
workshop.ask("why") // kyle why
  • when the instance doesn’t find a method on itself, goes up the prototype chain
  • in this case, workshop, the instance goes to Workshop’s prototype
  • note: the prototype chain is applicable for variables as well, not just methods

  • __proto__ is also called dunder proto
  • instance variables exist on that instance
  • we attach methods to the function prototype, so that all instances which we create can use it
  • when we make function calls and methods are not found, we go up the prototype chain
  • e.g. it will go to workshop, if the method is not found then to workshop.__proto__, then again to workshop.__proto__.__proto__ and so on
console.log(workshop.__proto__ === Workshop.prototype) // true
console.log(Workshop.prototype.__proto__ === Object.prototype) // true
console.log(Object.prototype.__proto__ === null) // true

console.log(Workshop === Workshop.prototype.constructor) // true
console.log(Object === Object.prototype.constructor) // true

Prototypal Polymorphism

  • we have to reference via __proto__ because this.ask would lead to infinite recursion
  • we had to use call on line 13 because if you look at the diagram above, properties are present on instances. by calling this.__proto__.ask, javascript looks for the teacher property on this.__proto__ due to implicit binding i.e. on Workshop.prototype, thus giving undefined
function Workshop(teacher) {
  this.teacher = teacher
}

Workshop.prototype.ask = function ask(question) {
  console.log(this.teacher, question)
}

var workshop = new Workshop("kyle")

workshop.ask = function ask(question) {
  this.__proto__.ask(question.toUpperCase()) // undefined 'why'
  this.__proto__.ask.call(this, question.toUpperCase()) // 'kyle' 'why'
}

workshop.ask("why")

Prototypal Inheritance

function Workshop(teacher) {
  this.teacher = teacher
}

Workshop.prototype.ask = function ask(question) {
  console.log(this.teacher, question)
}

function AnotherWorkshop(teacher) {
  Workshop.call(this, teacher)
}

AnotherWorkshop.prototype = Object.assign(AnotherWorkshop.prototype, Workshop.prototype)
// now all methods on Workshop.prototype exist on AnotherWorkshop.prototype

AnotherWorkshop.prototype.speakUp = function speakUp(question) {
  this.ask(question + "?")
}

var workshop = new AnotherWorkshop("kyle")
workshop.speakUp("why") // kyle why?
